transcript:
Therapist: Let's start by reviewing some of the thought records you've completed since our last session. Can you share an example of a situation where you used a thought record and what you discovered through the process?

Patient: Sure. Last week, I had a big project due for one of my classes, and I was feeling really overwhelmed and anxious about it. I noticed myself thinking, "I'm never going to be able to finish this on time" and "I'm going to fail this class." So, I decided to fill out a thought record.

Therapist: That's great that you recognized those negative thoughts and took the initiative to use a thought record. What did you discover as you worked through the columns of the thought record?

Patient: Well, in the evidence for and against columns, I realized that I was focusing only on the negative aspects of the situation and ignoring the evidence that contradicted my negative thoughts. For example, I've successfully completed projects like this before, and I had more time to work on it than I initially thought.

Therapist: That's a great insight. Recognizing that you were filtering out the positive aspects of the situation is an important step in challenging those negative thoughts. What was the outcome after you completed the thought record?

Patient: After I finished the thought record, I noticed that my anxiety had decreased from an 8 out of 10 to a 4 out of 10. I was able to reframe my original thought to something like, "I may be feeling overwhelmed right now, but I have successfully completed projects like this before, and I have enough time to break it down into manageable steps."

Therapist: That's a fantastic example of how thought records can help you challenge negative thoughts and reduce intense emotions. You did a great job of identifying the cognitive distortion of filtering and generating a more balanced alternative thought.

Patient: Thanks, it felt really empowering to be able to shift my perspective like that. I'm starting to see how my thoughts can really impact my emotions and behavior.

Therapist: Absolutely. That's a key concept in CBT – the connection between our thoughts, feelings, and actions. The more you practice using thought records, the more automatic it will become to challenge those negative thoughts when they arise.

Patient: I definitely want to keep practicing. It's just hard sometimes to remember to do it in the moment when I'm feeling really down or anxious.

Therapist: That's a common challenge. One strategy that can help is to schedule a regular time each day to review your thoughts and emotions, maybe in the evening before bed or first thing in the morning. That way, even if you don't catch the negative thoughts in the moment, you can still process them later.

Patient: That's a good idea. I think I could set aside some time in the evenings to review my day and fill out a thought record if needed.

Therapist: Let's talk a bit more about the downward arrow technique we introduced last session. Have you had a chance to practice using it to identify any underlying beliefs?

Patient: I've tried it a couple of times, but I'm not sure if I'm doing it right. Can you explain it again?

Therapist: Of course. The downward arrow technique is a way to uncover the deeper beliefs that underlie our automatic thoughts. You start with an automatic thought, like "I'm never going to be able to finish this project on time," and then you ask yourself, "If that were true, what would that mean about me or my life?" You keep asking that question until you arrive at a core belief, which is usually a broad, generalized statement about yourself, others, or the world.

Patient: Okay, I think I understand. So, if I start with the thought "I'm never going to be able to finish this project on time," I might ask myself, "If that were true, what would that mean about me?"

Therapist: Exactly. And what might your answer be to that question?

Patient: I guess if I couldn't finish the project on time, it would mean that I'm a failure or that I'm not capable of handling my responsibilities.

Therapist: Those sound like potential core beliefs. Let's keep going with the downward arrow technique. If you believed that you were a failure or not capable, what would that mean about you or your life?

Patient: It would mean that I'm not living up to my potential, and that I'm disappointing myself and others.

Therapist: Those are powerful statements, and they give us some insight into the deeper beliefs that might be driving some of your negative thoughts and emotions. We can start to explore and challenge those beliefs, just like we've been doing with your automatic thoughts.

Patient: That makes sense. It's just hard to think about challenging beliefs that feel so deeply ingrained.

Therapist: It can definitely feel daunting to challenge long-held beliefs. The key is to approach it gradually and with self-compassion. We can start by gathering evidence that contradicts those beliefs, just like we did with the evidence for and against columns in the thought record.

Patient: Okay, I'm willing to give it a try. It's just going to take some practice.

Therapist: Absolutely. And that's what we're here for – to practice these skills together. Remember, you've already made progress in challenging your negative thoughts, and that's a huge step in the right direction.

Patient: Thanks for the encouragement. I'm starting to feel more hopeful about being able to change some of these patterns.

Therapist: Your hopefulness is a great sign of progress. Let's keep building on that momentum. Before we move on to discussing stress management strategies, do you have any other questions or thoughts about the downward arrow technique or identifying core beliefs?

Patient: No, I think I have a better understanding now. I'm sure I'll have more questions as I practice it more, but I feel like I have a good starting point.

Therapist: Great. Let's shift gears a bit and talk about stress management. You mentioned earlier that you wanted to discuss some strategies for managing stress, especially with work and school. Can you tell me more about what's been stressful for you lately?
